awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Quantifiable Service Quality Firmware System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop technology to provide an in-depth downtime reduction analysis of computer-numerical controlled machines (CNCs), Additive Manufacturing (AM)/3D printing machines, computer-controlled appliances and complex engineered systems. The results of this project will affect a very large number of US CNC manufacturing facilities (over 19,000 CNC shops) as well as thousands of computer-controlled appliance repair companies, saving millions of dollars annually for the industry. The commercial potential of the project is is to minimize system downtime using service quality improvements. These groups of methods are analyzed and quantified using mathematical equations, algorithms, as well as visualization methods and tools. The results also will have an impact on manufacturing facilities and other complex engineered systems, such as robots, and cobots (collaborative robots), that have several complex computer-controlled, networked devices/instruments that need professional quality service to avoid downtime and failure.

This I-Corps project based on the development of technology for quantitative, predictive methods and tools that utilize quality-related key performance indicators (KPIs), that can be measured, calibrated, and enforced during service operations in computer-numerical controlled machines (CNCs), additive manufacturing (AM)/3D printing machines, and complex engineered systems.  Currently, there is no method or tool available for predicting the effectiveness or the level of success or risk of the services provided. The methods utilized are not systems engineering-focused, but rather financial accounting, and may or may not include reports of historical data to indicate the status of engineering-focused services provided. The technology under development is based on quantifiable service quality-focused key process/performance indicators (KPIs), using mathematical models, algorithms, and multimedia software visualization methods. This enables users to quantify levels of product/process quality service. In addition, the platform may be used to quantify and predict the product quality service as an index.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
Quantifiable Service Quality (QSQ) Firmware System: NSF I-Corps National Team Grant (Spring 2020): Paul G. Ranky (PI), Kevin Moriarty (EL), and Ray Vaccari (IM);  Awardee: New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT), NJ, Award Number: 2005314, Award Ends: 01/31/2021

Quantified Service Quality Firmware System: QSQ with a Complex CNC / computer controlled machine / robot / device / appliance / medical device focus (also considering major COVID-19 related challenges and disruptions, that started around the end of the first two months of our project).


Overview
We have found, that in the complex CNC (Computer Numerically Controlled), and AM (Additive Manufacturing) product-focused, computer controlled appliance, complex medical device engineered systems domain of the hi-tech service industry there are no quantitative, predictive methods and tools that utilize quality-related key performance indicators (KPIs), that can be measured, calibrated, and enforced before and during service operations. 
Also, we have found, that there was no method or tool available for predicting the effectiveness, or in other words the level of success of the service provided. Currently the methods utilized are not systems engineering focused, but rather financial accounting, and may or may not include reports of historical technical data to indicate the status of engineering-focused services provided.


This NSF funded project is very important for both consumers / users, as well as manufacturers / designers, because a successful product design always goes hand-in-hand with a successful hi-tech service support system. Therefore good quality products must have good quality engineering-focused service too, at all levels of the enterprise, including the customer.


As a result of this project we have identified key process indicators, parameters, created new mathematical models and methods, analyzed user requirements, the requirements of manufacturers for a Quantified Service Quality Firmware System: QSQ with a Complex CNC / computer controlled machine / robot / device / appliance / medical device focus.  We have also considered and added solutions relating to COVID-19 related challenges. This pandemic had a major impact on our project because it was restricting CDI (Customer Discovery) related travel, nevertheless we have managed to complete over 187 new CDIs. (We had an NSF I-corps NJIT node grant before this grant for which we have also completed 47 plus CDIs. That is in addition to the new 187 CDIs, therefore the real CDI total is 47+187= 234.


Keywords: quality, service, CNC manufacturing, Computer Numerical Control, AM, Additive Manufacturing, complex medical device, computer controlled appliance, COVID-19 challenges in service quality, product design, maintenance

Intellectual Merit
There are several novel features of the team’s core solution. First, the team’s methods and tools are based on Key Process/ performance Indicators (KPIs), attributes, using the team’s own mathematical models, algorithms and software visualization methods. This enables the team to quantify levels of product quality service. Another novel feature of our project is to use a newly developed unique, a patentable mathematical Modular Transform to analyze and generate a key performance indicator to predict the product quality service index.


The research we have completed, as well as the proposed research, methods and tools will also provide an in-depth market analysis of CNC, AM engineered system and computer controlled appliance down time reduction. The goal is to minimize system down time and offer waste reduction methods and techniques by means of quantifiable service quality improvements. These groups of methods will be / have been analyzed and quantified using mathematical equations, algorithms, as well as visualization methods and tools by the team’s firmware product, for which the team is working on to get a US patent. 

Broader Impacts
The team is confident that this integrated and networked firmware product, and the quality service system modeling method and management decision toolkit has the potential for broad societal impacts. The customer discovery and market research conducted during this grant and the over 187 CDIs (Customer Discovery Interviews) completed in very difficult COVID-19 times, when travel was restricted, will lead to the creation of a startup company that would impact over 90% of the small-to-medium size CNC / AM (Additive Manufacturing) and other computer controlled device user / manufacturing enterprises in the USA. Furthermore, to increase the broader impact of the work, besides selling the firmware product and conducting consulting activities for profit, the team is also protecting the IP through patents and then educate the community using the American Society for Quality (ASQ) and other educational and commercial sources on this novel, systematic system analysis and design framework.

Publications / papers / conference papers in preparation / already published (ref. this grant): the total number = 19 (15 already published). 


Last Modified: 02/28/2021
Modified by: Paul G Ranky
